column2: The destruction of mankind came not as the fiat of an arbitrary Deity, but because of the purpose which God had before him in the work of creation, and because that purpose was good.
column3: The destruction of mankind came not as the fiat of an arbitrary Deity, but because of the purpose which God had before him in the work of creation, and because that purpose was good.

column2: Men by their sins and wilful failure to observe his benign laws were thwarting that purpose.
column3: Men by their sins and wilful failure to observe his benign laws were thwarting that purpose.

column2: Hence in accord with the just laws of the universe their destruction was unavoidable, and it came even as effect follows cause.

column2: On the other hand, these ancient teachers taught with inimitable skill that God would not destroy that which was worthy of preservation.

column2: In each of the accounts the character of Noah stands in striking contrast with those of his contemporaries.
column3: In each of the accounts the character of Noah stands in striking contrast with those of his contemporaries.

column2: The story as told is not merely an illustration of the truth that righteousness brings its just reward, but of the profounder principle that it is the morally fit who survive.
column3: The story as told is not merely an illustration of the truth that righteousness brings its just reward, but of the profounder principle that it is the morally fit who survive.

column2: To him are given the promises which God was eager to realize in the life of humanity.

column2: SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST IN THE NATURAL WORLD.
column3: SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST IN THE NATURAL WORLD.

column2: It is interesting and illuminating to note how the ancient Hebrew prophets in their religious teaching forecast the discoveries and scientific methods of our day.
column3: It is interesting and illuminating to note how the ancient Hebrew prophets in their religious teaching forecast the discoveries and scientific methods of our day.

column2: This was because they had grasped universal principles.
column3: This was because they had grasped universal principles.

column2: Since the memorable evening in July, 1858, in which the views of Darwin and Wallace on the principles of variation and selection in the natural world were sent to the Linnaean Society in London, the leading scientists have laid great stress upon the doctrine of the survival of the "fittest" as the true explanation of progress in the natural world.
column3: Since the memorable evening in July, eighteen fifty eight, in which the views of Darwin and Wallace on the principles of variation and selection in the natural world were sent to the Linnaean Society in London, the leading scientists have laid great stress upon the doctrine of the survival of the "fittest" as the true explanation of progress in the natural world.

column2: It was apparently made clear by Darwin, and supported by sufficient evidence, that "any being, if it vary however slightly, in any manner profitable to itself, under the complex and somewhat varying conditions of life, will have a better chance of surviving, and thus be naturally selected."
column3: It was apparently made clear by Darwin, and supported by sufficient evidence, that "any being, if it vary however slightly, in any manner profitable to itself, under the complex and somewhat varying conditions of life, will have a better chance of surviving, and thus be naturally selected."

column2: This principle, since that day, has been thoroughly worked out in practically all the important fields of both the plant and animal world.
column3: This principle, since that day, has been thoroughly worked out in practically all the important fields of both the plant and animal world.

column2: Moreover, the doctrine of evolution, dependent upon this principle, has exerted so great an influence upon the process of investigation and thinking in all fields of activity that the resulting change in method has amounted to a revolution.
column3: Moreover, the doctrine of evolution, dependent upon this principle, has exerted so great an influence upon the process of investigation and thinking in all fields of activity that the resulting change in method has amounted to a revolution.

column2: The principle is applied not only in the field of biology, but also in the realm of astronomy, where we study the evolution of worlds, and in psychology, history, social science, where we speak of the development of human traits and of the growth of economic, political and social institutions.
column3: The principle is applied not only in the field of biology, but also in the realm of astronomy, where we study the evolution of worlds, and in psychology, history, social science, where we speak of the development of human traits and of the growth of economic, political and social institutions.

column2: It is necessary to remember in applying such a brief statement of a principle, that the words are used in a highly technical sense. The word "fittest" by no means need imply the best from the point of view of beauty or strength or usefulness in nature; nor does it necessarily mean, in reference to society, best from the point of view of morals or a higher civilization.
column3: It is necessary to remember in applying such a brief statement of a principle, that the words are used in a highly technical sense. The word "fittest" by no means need imply the best from the point of view of beauty or strength or usefulness in nature; nor does it necessarily mean, in reference to society, best from the point of view of morals or a higher civilization.

column2: Rather the "fittest" means the being best adapted to the conditions under which it is living, or to its environment.
column3: Rather the "fittest" means the being best adapted to the conditions under which it is living, or to its environment.

column2: As a matter of fact, it is the general opinion that in practically all fields this principle works toward progress in the highest and best sense; but it is always a matter for specific study as well as of great scientific interest and importance, to determine where and how the variation and the corresponding selection tend to promote the morally good. Especially is this true in the study of society, where we should endeavor to see whether or not the "fittest" means also the highest from the moral and religious point of view.
column3: As a matter of fact, it is the general opinion that in practically all fields this principle works toward progress in the highest and best sense; but it is always a matter for specific study as well as of great scientific interest and importance, to determine where and how the variation and the corresponding selection tend to promote the morally good. Especially is this true in the study of society, where we should endeavor to see whether or not the "fittest" means also the highest from the moral and religious point of view.

column2: The story of the flood gives us a most interesting example of the way in which the ancient Hebrews looked upon such a process of selection in the moral and religious world and taught it as a divine principle.
column3: The story of the flood gives us a most interesting example of the way in which the ancient hebrews looked upon such a process of selection in the moral and religious world and taught it as a divine principle.

column2: It is, therefore, one of the most suggestive and interesting of the writings of the early Israelites.
column3: It is, therefore, one of the most suggestive and interesting of the writings of the early Israelites.

column2: THE SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST IN SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE.
column3: THE SURVIVAL OF THE FITTEST IN SOCIAL AND POLITICAL LIFE.

column2: From our modern point of view, the ancient Hebrew writers had a far deeper knowledge of moral and religious questions than of natural science.
column3: From our modern point of view, the ancient Hebrew writers had a far deeper knowledge of moral and religious questions than of natural science.

column2: They had a far keener sense of what was socially beneficial than of what was scientifically true.
column3: They had a far keener sense of what was socially beneficial than of what was scientifically true.

column2: However we may estimate their knowledge of geology and biology, we must grant that their beliefs regarding the good and ill effects of human action have in them much that is universally true, even though we may not follow them throughout in their theories of divine wrath and immediate earthly punishment of the wicked.
column3: However we may estimate their knowledge of geology and biology, we must grant that their beliefs regarding the good and ill effects of human action have in them much that is universally true, even though we may not follow them throughout in their theories of divine wrath and immediate earthly punishment of the wicked.

column2: But is it not true almost invariably, if we look at social questions of every kind in a comprehensive way, that the survival of the fittest means the survival of the morally best?

column2: That the religion which endures is of the highest type?

column2: Business success in the long run, is so strongly based upon mutual confidence and trust, that, especially in these later days of credit organization, the dishonest man or even the tricky man cannot prosper long.

column2: For the sake of making an important sale they were often inclined to misrepresent his goods.
column3: For the sake of making an important sale they were often inclined to misrepresent his goods.

column2: But nothing, he added, "will so surely kill all business as misrepresentation." Even a gambling book-maker on the race tracks in New York, before such work was forbidden by law, is said to have proudly claimed that absolute justice and honesty toward his customers was essential to his success and had therefore become the rule of his life. Although it is sometimes said that the man who guides his life by the maxim, "Honesty is the best policy," is in reality not honest at heart, it must nevertheless be granted that in business the survival of the fittest means the survival of the most honest business man.
column3: But nothing, he added, "will so surely kill all business as misrepresentation." column2: It may perhaps have been true in the days of Machiavelli that cruelty and treachery would aid the unscrupulous petty despot of Italy to secure and at times to maintain his dukedom; but certainly in modern days, when in all civilized countries permanently prosperous government is based ultimately upon the will of the people, the successful ruler can no longer be treacherous and cruel.
